Radium was mixed with zinc sulfide to create paint that glowed without an external light source (now banned due to health risks)
Precursor for Actinium
Used in nuclear reactors to produce the next element for medical use
The neutron irradiation of Radium-226 is one method used to produce the medically important isotope Actinium-227
sources: Rocks that are mainly mined for Uranium (pitchblende is one kind).
Rocks that are mainly mined for the metal Vanadium.
Rocks mined for fertilizer that have small amounts of Radium.
Old medical tools or paint that used Radium (now recycled).
ccs: Used to make the special medical isotope Radium-223 for treating bone cancer.
Historically used in early radiation research and sometimes to make materials glow (now known to be dangerous!).
A chemical form that is often seen in old, slightly radioactive waste from the time radium was first used.

ffs: Actinium glows in the dark with a ghostly blue light.
It was the first non-uranium element discovered to be radioactive.
Its name comes from the Greek word for “ray” due to its radiation.
apps: Targeted Alpha Therapy
Used in cutting-edge, highly effective cancer treatment
Actinium-225 is an extremely powerful isotope for Targeted Alpha Therapy (TAT), destroying small clusters of cancer cells with minimal damage to nearby healthy tissue
Generator for Bismuth-213
Used to produce another short-lived radioisotope for immediate medical use
Actinium-225 decays into Bismuth-213, which is then used as a highly effective, short-lived alpha-emitter in medicine
Neutron Sources (Research)
Used in niche, specialized studies as a high-intensity neutron emitter
Like Radium, Actinium can be mixed with Beryllium to create a powerful source of neutrons
Radioactivity Standards
Used in laboratories to calibrate radiation detection equipment
Its specific and well-understood decay properties make it useful for setting the standard for measuring other radioactive sources
sources: Rocks that are mainly mined for Uranium, but only tiny amounts remain.
A metal that is placed inside a nuclear reactor to create Actinium.
A metal that is hit with particles in a lab to create Actinium.
It is carefully separated from many other materials found in the rock.
ccs: Used in research as a precursor to make the powerful, cancer-fighting isotope Actinium-225.
Used in special labs to study the unique chemistry of this rare, radioactive element.
Used to separate actinium from other metals in a lab through special chemical processes.

ffs: Named after Thor, the Norse god of thunder.
Thorium was once used in gas lantern mantles that glowed brightly.
Some think it could fuel cleaner nuclear reactors in the future.
apps: Nuclear Reactor Fuel (Future)
Used as a fertile material that can be converted into nuclear fuel
Thorium-232 is a fertile isotope that can be bred into fissile Uranium-233, an attractive alternative to Uranium fuel
High-Temperature Ceramics
Used to make extremely heat-resistant materials
Thorium dioxide has the highest melting point of any oxide (approx. 3300°C) and is used in specialized high-temperature crucibles and electrodes
Gas Lantern Mantles (Historical)
Used to create the bright, stable light in portable lanterns
Thorium dioxide was the main component in Welsbach mantles, glowing brightly when heated by a gas flame
Specialized Glass Optics
Used to produce high-quality camera and instrument lenses
Thorium is added to glass to create high-refractive-index lenses, but this use is declining due to its slight radioactivity
sources: Heavy, dark sand that has rare metals and Thorium in it.
A rock that is rich in Thorium and Silicon.
Rocks that are mainly mined for the metal Tin.
Used chemical speed-boosters from old industrial processes.
ccs: This super strong ceramic is used to make parts that need to resist incredibly high heat, like crucibles.
A material studied for use in special molten salt nuclear reactors as a potential fuel source.
Historically used in tiny amounts to help make gas lantern mantles glow very brightly.

ffs: It's so rare that for decades only a few grams existed in the entire world.
Early researchers had to isolate it from tons of uranium ore.
apps: Thorium Reactor Research
Studied for its role in next-generation nuclear reactors.
The isotope Protactinium-233 is important in the Thorium fuel cycle for breeding Uranium-233.
Uranium Decay Studies
Used to understand the natural decay chain of Uranium.
Protactinium is a natural step between the decay of Uranium-235 and the formation of Actinium.
Ocean Dating
Scientists use its decay rate to date deep-sea materials.
The ratio of Protactinium-231 to Thorium-230 is used to measure how long sediments have been on the ocean floor.
Chemical Separation Research
Used to develop methods for separating radioactive elements.
Due to its unique chemistry, it helps test methods for isolating different actinides during nuclear waste processing.
sources: Rocks that are mainly mined for Uranium.
A tiny amount is naturally made when Uranium-235 breaks down.
The fuel rods taken out of a nuclear power plant.
Waste material left over after processing Uranium ore.
ccs: This compound is a stable white solid that scientists can make to study Protactinium safely in the lab.
This compound is used to help purify Protactinium from the other elements it is mixed with after being made in a reactor.
This compound is one of the easiest ways to dissolve Protactinium for chemical experiments.

ffs: Named after the planet Uranus—discovered shortly after the planet was.
It's the fuel behind both nuclear power and nuclear weapons.
apps: Nuclear Power Fuel
Used as the main fuel to produce electricity in nuclear reactors.
Uranium-235 atoms are split (fission) to release large amounts of heat energy.
Nuclear Weapons
The key ingredient for creating atomic bombs.
Highly enriched Uranium-235 is needed to create the chain reaction used in fission weapons.
Depleted Uranium (DU)
Used in armor plating and armor-piercing military munitions.
The dense, heavy waste from enriching Uranium is used because it is much harder than steel.
Glass Colorant
Used in small amounts to give glass a yellow-green color and a glow.
Uranium glass (or Vaseline glass) was popular in the past
it glows brightly under UV light.
sources: Dark rocks that contain a lot of Uranium and other elements.
Rocks mined for fertilizer that have small amounts of Uranium.
A very small amount is dissolved in the world's oceans.
Uranium that is taken out of used reactor fuel and cleaned.
ccs: This is the main compound used to make the solid fuel pellets that power nuclear reactors.
This is a gas used in a special factory process to separate the Uranium-235 needed for fuel from the much more common Uranium-238.
This is a common yellow powder that is an important step when preparing Uranium for use as fuel.

ffs: Named after Neptune because it comes after Uranium in the periodic table.
It's a byproduct of nuclear reactors.
The U.S. briefly looked into using it for nuclear bombs—but passed.
apps: Plutonium-238 Production
Used as a starting material to create Plutonium-238.
Neptunium-237 is bombarded with neutrons to produce the special Plutonium isotope used in space probes.
Nuclear Waste Study
A long-lived component of nuclear waste that must be managed.
Scientists study Neptunium's behavior to find ways to safely store or reuse nuclear waste over millions of years.
Neutron Detection
Can be used in devices that detect high-energy neutrons.
Neptunium's nuclear properties make it suitable for measuring neutron levels in specific experiments.
Basic Nuclear Physics
Used in research to understand transuranic element chemistry.
Since it is the first synthetic element, studying it helps predict the properties of heavier elements.
sources: The fuel rods taken out of a nuclear power plant.
It is made in reactors as a byproduct of making Plutonium-239.
A tiny, tiny amount is naturally made when Uranium breaks down.
Uranium targets hit with neutrons to purposely create Neptunium.
ccs: This dark brown or black solid is the most common and stable form of Neptunium to study in the laboratory.
Fluoride compounds are often made by scientists to help separate Neptunium from other elements and purify it.
This compound is a special kind of Neptunium oxide that is very reactive and interesting for chemists to study.

ffs: Named after Pluto, the former planet, following the space-theme trend.
Plutonium is famously dangerous—and was used in the Nagasaki bomb.
It glows faintly from its own heat!
apps: Nuclear Reactor Fuel
Used in some power plants to create MOX (Mixed-Oxide) fuel.
Plutonium-239 created from used Uranium can be recycled and mixed with Uranium oxide to make new fuel rods.
Space Probe Power (RTGs)
Used to power deep-space probes where sunlight is too weak.
Plutonium-238's heat from decay is converted to electricity using devices called RTGs (Radioisotope Thermoelectric Generators).
Fission Weapons Core
The key material for the inner core of modern nuclear weapons.
Plutonium-239 is highly fissile, meaning it easily splits to create a powerful nuclear explosion.
Heart Pacemaker Power
Historically used to provide long-lasting, reliable power for heart devices.
Tiny amounts of Plutonium-238 were used in early pacemakers because of its long, steady heat output.
sources: The fuel rods taken out of a nuclear power plant.
Uranium metal that is hit with particles inside a special reactor.
Tiny, tiny amounts are sometimes found naturally in Uranium ore.
Special preparation of Neptunium-237 to create Plutonium-238.
ccs: This is the most common compound used to store Plutonium and is a key part of MOX (Mixed-Oxide) reactor fuel.
This compound is a purple crystal that is sometimes used in the process of turning Plutonium into a metal.
This is a blue-green solid used by scientists to study how Plutonium dissolves and reacts in liquids.

ffs: Found in smoke detectors in many homes.
It was created in a lab, not found in nature.
apps: Smoke Detector Source
A small piece is used to detect smoke in common home alarms.
Americium-241 sends out alpha particles to create an electric current, and smoke particles disrupt this current and trigger the alarm.
Industrial Gauging
Used in measuring devices for metal thickness and other materials.
The element's radiation can be used to measure the thickness of materials like sheet metal and glass without touching them.
Medical Diagnostics
Used in a device to check for thyroid disorders and bone mineral density.
Americium-241 sources are sometimes used in specific X-ray and imaging devices.
Heavy Element Production
Used as a starting material to create much heavier elements.
It is bombarded with neutrons to make Curium (Cm) and other transcurium elements.
sources: The fuel rods taken out of a nuclear power plant.
Plutonium that is hit with particles inside a special reactor.
Plutonium from old nuclear weapons that is now used to make Americium.
Tiny amounts formed from the natural breakdown of heavier elements.
ccs: This is the material inside your smoke detector! It's the most common form of Americium used in technology.
This is a pink salt that scientists use to study the chemistry of Americium.
This is an easily dissolved compound used in liquid solutions to study Americium's behavior.

ffs: Named after Marie and Pierre Curie.
It's so radioactive it glows in the dark.
It was discovered in the fallout of early atomic bomb tests.
apps: Space Probe Analysis (APXS)
Used in tools carried on Mars Rovers to study rock chemistry.
Curium-244 is part of a machine that shoots alpha particles at a rock to learn what elements it is made of.
Radioisotope Heat Source
Used to generate heat for devices needing a steady temperature in space.
Curium-244 gives off a lot of heat when it decays, making it useful for small, long-term power or heat units.
Basic Nuclear Research
A valuable element for understanding actinide chemical behavior.
Scientists study its properties to better predict how similar, short-lived elements will behave.
Heavy Element Synthesis
Used as a key step in creating the heaviest known man-made elements.
It is a target material that is bombarded with other atoms to create new, super-heavy elements like Berkelium.
sources: The fuel rods taken out of a nuclear power plant.
Americium that is hit with particles inside a special reactor.
Plutonium that is hit with particles inside a special reactor.
Tiny amounts found after very powerful hydrogen bomb tests.
ccs: This compound is a common, stable form of Curium, sometimes used in small heat or power sources for space missions.
This fluoride is made as a way to purify Curium for science experiments.
This compound dissolves easily in water, which makes it easy for scientists to study Curium's properties in solution.

ffs: It was first made in a cyclotron in 1949.
Very few people outside nuclear labs have ever worked with it.
apps: Synthesis of New Elements
A crucial material used to create even heavier, exotic elements.
Berkelium-249 atoms were used to create Tennessine (Element 117) by bombarding them with Calcium ions.
Research Element
It is produced in special nuclear reactors only for scientific study.
Since it is extremely rare and radioactive, its only purpose is for research into nuclear structure and chemical properties.
Tracer Studies
Used to follow chemical reactions in the lab due to its easy-to-track radiation.
Its radioactivity allows scientists to track how its compounds move and react in very small-scale experiments.
Understanding Actinide Bonding
Studied to understand how the f-electrons (inner shell) bond in the actinide series.
Chemists use it to figure out the complex and varied oxidation states of the transuranic metals.
sources: Curium that is hit with particles inside a special reactor.
Made by adding neutrons to Curium or Americium in a powerful reactor.
Tiny amounts found after very powerful hydrogen bomb tests.
It is purified from other heavy elements created in the reactor.
ccs: This is a common compound scientists make to study the solid form of Berkelium.
This compound is used to help turn Berkelium into its pure metal form.
This salt is useful for small chemical experiments because it dissolves well in the strong acids used in nuclear chemistry.

ffs: Named after California and the University of California.
A piece the size of a grain of salt costs millions of dollars!
It can detect gold and silver underground in mining operations.
apps: Neutron Start-Up Source
Used to safely start up nuclear reactors.
Californium-252 sends out many neutrons, providing the initial particles to begin the chain reaction in a reactor core.
Cancer Treatment (Brachytherapy)
Used in a form of therapy to directly treat certain tumors.
Tiny sources of Californium-252 are placed inside a tumor to kill cancer cells with its high-energy neutron radiation.
Oil and Mineral Prospecting
Used to map and locate oil, water, or minerals underground.
A small source is sent into boreholes (wells) to look for valuable elements through a process called neutron activation analysis.
Aircraft Inspection
Used in portable devices to check for small cracks and flaws in metal parts.
Its neutron beam is used to perform non-destructive testing on jet engine parts and airplane structures.
sources: Curium that is hit with particles inside a special reactor.
Americium that is hit with particles inside a special reactor.
Made by adding many neutrons to lighter elements in a powerful reactor.
Tiny amounts found after very powerful hydrogen bomb tests.
ccs: This is a common compound scientists make to store and study Californium in its solid form.
This compound is a green-yellow color and is used in liquid experiments to see how Californium reacts.
This is used in the process of creating the pure metal of Californium for specialized uses.

ffs: It was discovered in the debris of the first hydrogen bomb test.
It's almost impossible to study—it decays too fast.
apps: First Synthesizer of Mendelevium
Used to create the next element, Mendelevium (Z=101).
Einsteinium-253 was bombarded with alpha particles to produce the first atoms of Mendelevium.
Research Element
It is only used for basic scientific research due to its rarity and fast decay.
Scientists study its complex chemical properties to fill in the gaps of the periodic table, element by element.
Nuclear Test Analysis
Its discovery confirmed the process of multiple neutron capture in nuclear explosions.
Finding it in the H-bomb fallout proved that Uranium atoms captured a large number of neutrons in an instant.
Actinide Chemistry Model
Studied to predict the properties of elements even harder to make and analyze.
Despite its difficulties, studying Einsteinium's reactions helps create a chemical model for the heaviest elements.
sources: Californium that is hit with particles inside a special reactor.
Made by adding many neutrons to lighter elements in a powerful reactor.
Found in the ash and dust after a hydrogen bomb test.
It is carefully purified from other heavy elements created in the reactor.
ccs: This is the most common compound of Einsteinium, made in tiny amounts for scientists to study its properties.
This compound is a pink solid that is used to study how Einsteinium reacts with chlorine.
Since it dissolves, this compound lets scientists examine how Einsteinium behaves in liquid solutions, even with very small samples.

ffs: Named after Enrico Fermi, a pioneer of nuclear physics.
Like Einsteinium, it was discovered in H-bomb test fallout.
It's so radioactive that samples can only be made in minute amounts.
apps: Nuclear Physics Research
Used only in very small amounts for the most fundamental scientific studies.
It is the heaviest element that can be made by neutron capture (adding neutrons to lighter atoms) in a nuclear reactor.
Studying Fission Barriers
Research into its isotopes helps scientists understand spontaneous nuclear fission.
Fermium isotopes show a point where adding more neutrons makes the nucleus break apart very quickly on its own.
Chemical Behavior Model
Used to study the last elements of the actinide series before the f-shell is full.
Its chemistry (especially the shift to the +2 oxidation state) helps define the end of the actinide block.
Confirming Theoretical Models
Its existence and decay properties confirm key theories in nuclear structure.
The measured properties of its isotopes are compared with computer models to prove our understanding of the atomic nucleus.
sources: Einsteinium that is hit with particles inside a special reactor.
Made by adding many neutrons to lighter elements in a powerful reactor.
Found in the ash and dust after a hydrogen bomb test.
It is purified from other heavy elements created in the reactor.
ccs: Scientists think this would be the most stable compound of Fermium if they could ever make enough of it.
This compound is used in computer models to predict how Fermium would react with other chemicals.
Because Fermium is so rare and short-lived, its compounds are mostly studied using computer simulations.

ffs: Named after Dmitri Mendeleev, creator of the periodic table.
It was made by smashing atoms together—very sci-fi.
Only tiny atoms at a time can be created and studied.
apps: Basic Nuclear Research
Used to study the limits of nuclear stability and structure.
Scientists use it to learn how many protons and neutrons an atomic nucleus can hold before it falls apart.
Actinide Chemical Studies
Crucial for understanding how the heavier actinide elements behave chemically.
Its reactions help confirm the pattern of electron shells at the end of the actinide series.
Synthesis of New Elements
Its isotopes are sometimes used to create even heavier, more exotic elements.
Although rare, it can be used as a target material in powerful particle accelerators.
Trace Chemistry Techniques
Only studied using very fast and sensitive techniques due to its short life.
Its difficulty forces scientists to invent better methods for working with tiny, short-lived amounts of material.
sources: Einsteinium-253 atoms hit with helium nuclei (alpha particles).
Californium atoms hit with energetic particles in a reactor.
The process of fusing lighter atoms into Mendelevium.
The decay product of some heavier, man-made elements.
ccs: Because this element lasts for such a short time, scientists use computers to predict how this compound would look and act.
This compound is expected to dissolve in water and is used in theoretical chemistry to predict Mendelevium's behavior.
Scientists believe this compound would be the most stable solid form, but they haven't been able to make enough atoms to confirm it.

ffs: Named after Alfred Nobel, founder of the Nobel Prizes.
It was first claimed by scientists in Sweden.
There was a naming dispute between Russia and America for years.
apps: Study of Divalent State
Key element for studying the +2 oxidation state in the actinide series.
Its ability to form a No<sup>2+</sup> ion is a major focus for chemists trying to understand electron structure.
End-of-Actinide Chemistry
Its properties define the end of the rare earth elements on the periodic table.
As the next-to-last actinide, its chemical behavior is important for understanding the whole group.
Nuclear Structure Theory
Used in research to test theoretical models of the atomic nucleus.
Studying how its various isotopes decay helps scientists confirm nuclear physics calculations.
Preparation for Trans-Actinides
Research on Nobelium helps develop techniques for studying heavier elements.
The fast chemistry methods used to study it are necessary for the even shorter-lived super-heavy elements that follow.
sources: Curium-246 atoms hit with Carbon-12 ions.
Californium atoms hit with energetic particles in a reactor.
The process of fusing lighter atoms into Nobelium.
The decay product of some heavier, man-made elements (e.g., Rutherfordium).
ccs: Chemists try to make this compound to compare Nobelium's properties with its neighbors in the periodic table.
This compound is used in liquid chemistry experiments to study how Nobelium's ions behave in a solution.
This is the predicted stable solid form, which scientists hope to create to measure its melting point and density.

ffs: Named after Ernest Lawrence, inventor of the cyclotron.
Its chemistry was hard to study because it's so short-lived.
apps: Defining the Periodic Table
Marks the end of the actinide series (f-block) and the start of the transition metals (d-block).
Its chemical properties confirm where the row of inner transition elements officially stops.
Relativistic Chemistry
Used to study how extremely fast-moving electrons change its chemical behavior.
Because the nucleus is so large, its electrons are very fast, which changes how it forms chemical bonds.
Advanced Synthesis Research
Scientists focus on improving methods for creating and isolating its short-lived atoms.
The techniques needed to make and study Lawrencium paved the way for creating all the elements that follow it.
Prediction of Super-Heavy Properties
As the first element with a 7p electron in theory, it informs chemical predictions for elements like Eka-Lawrencium (Z=153).
Its position and behavior are used to predict the chemical traits of even heavier elements that have not yet been made.
sources: Californium isotopes hit with Boron or Carbon ions.
Particle accelerators (e.g., Berkeley, USA, and Dubna, Russia)
The process of fusing lighter atoms into Lawrencium.
The decay product of some heavier, man-made elements (e.g., Dubnium).
Purified from complex mixtures of other heavy elements.
ccs: Chemists look at how this compound reacts to decide where Lawrencium really belongs on the periodic table.
This compound is made in liquid solutions to study how Lawrencium's ions behave very quickly before they decay.
As a theoretical solid, its properties are studied to understand the limits of solid chemical structures in the heaviest elements.

ffs: Named after Ernest Rutherford, the father of nuclear physics.
It was part of a naming controversy between American and Russian scientists.
It doesn't exist naturally—only made in labs.
apps: Start of d-Block Chemistry
The first element in the 6d transition metal series (Group 4).
Its chemical reactions are compared to lighter elements like Hafnium (Hf) and Zirconium (Zr) to check periodic trends.
Gas-Phase Chemistry
One of the few super-heavy elements whose chemical reactions have been studied as a gas.
Experiments have been done on its chloride compound (RfCl4+) to test its boiling point and adsorption properties.
Element Synthesis Target
Used in attempts to create even heavier elements by bombarding it with lighter atoms.
The few atoms of Rutherfordium that are made are sometimes used as building blocks for new elements.
Nuclear Half-Life Study
Research focuses on creating its most stable isotope, Rutherfordium-267.
A more stable isotope allows scientists to perform longer chemical experiments and better understand its properties.
sources: Californium-249 atoms hit with Carbon-12 ions.
Plutonium-242 atoms hit with Neon-22 ions.
The process of fusing lighter atoms into Rutherfordium.
The decay product of some heavier, man-made elements (e.g., Seaborgium).
ccs: This compound is a gas that scientists make to see how quickly it moves and compare it to other elements in its column.
This is the predicted solid oxide, which helps chemists predict its melting point and other physical properties.

ffs: Named after Dubna, Russia, where it was first synthesized.
It had a Cold War-era naming rivalry: Americans wanted to call it “Hahnium.”
It's so unstable it vanishes in seconds.
apps: Group 5 Chemistry Check
Studied to see if it acts like its lighter family members: Tantalum and Niobium.
Its chemical properties are mostly an extension of Group 5 on the periodic table, forming +5 compounds.
Volatility Experiments
Focus is on measuring how easily its compounds turn into gas (volatility).
Scientists look at the speed its compounds move through gases to figure out its chemical type.
Predicting Relativity Effects
Tests theoretical chemistry that predicts how fast electrons affect its chemical bonds.
Due to its extremely high atomic number, its electrons move very fast, creating special chemical effects.
New Element Production
Used in a particle accelerator as a temporary link to form other elements.
The short-lived atoms of Dubnium help create a path to form elements with even higher atomic numbers.
sources: Californium-249 atoms hit with Nitrogen-15 ions.
Americium-243 atoms hit with Neon-22 ions.
The process of fusing lighter atoms into Dubnium.
The decay product of some heavier, man-made elements (e.g., Bohrium).
ccs: This compound is made as a gas in special labs to check if Dubnium acts like the other elements in its column.
Scientists use this compound to test their theories about how strong Dubnium's chemical bonds are.

ffs: Named after Glenn Seaborg—while he was still alive!
Controversial for being the first element named after a living person.
It's extremely radioactive and decays almost instantly.
apps: Group 6 Chemistry Model
Used to confirm the chemical trends of Group 6, along with Tungsten and Molybdenum.
It forms stable 6+ compounds, showing that the chemical pattern of the column holds true even for heavy elements.
Creation of Oxochlorides
Scientists successfully created a compound that acts like a gas (SgO2C2).
This compound allows researchers to study the element's chemical properties by watching how the gas interacts with surfaces.
Proving Periodicity
Its chemical studies help prove that the periodic table structure works even for synthetic elements.
Studying its behavior shows that even super-heavy elements follow the rules predicted by the table.
Accelerator Design
Its discovery and study push engineers to build more powerful and precise particle accelerators.
Creating and detecting such rare atoms requires constant improvements in accelerator technology.
sources: Californium-249 atoms hit with Oxygen-18 ions.
Lead-208 atoms hit with Chromium-54 ions (cold fusion).
The process of fusing lighter atoms into Seaborgium.
The decay product of some heavier, man-made elements (e.g., Hassium).
ccs: This is the first Seaborgium compound ever studied! Scientists use it to see if Seaborgium belongs in Group 6.
This compound is a predicted gas that helps scientists compare Seaborgium to Tungsten in the periodic table.

ffs: Named after Niels Bohr, a pioneer of atomic theory.
It was first created in Germany in 1981.
Has no practical use—just scientific curiosity!
apps: Group 7 Chemistry Check
Studied to compare its behavior to Manganese, Technetium, and Rhenium.
Its ability to form a volatile oxide (BhO3) confirms that it belongs in Group 7.
Advanced Ion-Exchange Studies
Used to test new methods for separating and identifying single atoms.
The tiny number of atoms created require very fast, highly selective chemical methods to even study.
Nuclear Fission Research
Scientists study how its isotopes break apart (fission) to understand nuclear stability.
Its extremely short half-life helps scientists map the 'valley of stability' for heavy nuclei.
Theoretical Predictions
Its successful synthesis confirms models used to predict the stability of super-heavy elements.
Finding an element as heavy as Bohrium proves that we can accurately predict nuclear creation in accelerators.
sources: Bismuth-209 atoms hit with Chromium-54 ions (cold fusion).
Berkelium-249 atoms hit with Oxygen-18 ions.
The process of fusing lighter atoms into Bohrium.
The decay product of some heavier, man-made elements (e.g., Meitnerium).
ccs: Chemists make this compound to compare Bohrium to the element directly above it, Rhenium, to see if they react the same way.
This is a gas compound that has been detected by scientists, which helps confirm Bohrium's spot in Group 7.

ffs: Named after Hesse, the German state.
Exists for only a few seconds at a time.
Scientists try to study its chemistry one atom at a time.
apps: Group 8 Chemical Analogy
Its oxide (HsO4) is studied to see if it perfectly mimics Osmium (OsO4) from Group 8.
The compound's volatility (how easily it becomes a gas) confirms its placement directly below Osmium on the table.
Search for the Island of Stability
One of the elements scientists study as part of the search for very long-lived super-heavy elements.
Its stability is slightly higher than its neighbors, offering clues to where the theoretical Island of Stability might be.
Single-Atom Chemistry
Its rarity forces chemists to develop techniques that can study the properties of just one atom.
The methods developed for Hassium allow scientists to perform chemistry with the smallest possible amount of matter.
Exploring Relativistic Effects
Its chemical properties are checked against predictions that account for the speed of its inner electrons.
Scientists use its data to confirm that Einstein's theory of relativity plays a role in the chemistry of heavy elements.
sources: Lead-208 atoms hit with Iron-58 ions (cold fusion).
Bismuth-209 atoms hit with Manganese-55 ions.
The process of fusing lighter atoms into Hassium.
The decay product of some heavier, man-made elements (e.g., Darmstadtium).
ccs: This gas compound is studied because it acts exactly like the gas formed by its lighter cousin, Osmium, proving the periodic table works!

ffs: Named after Lise Meitner, who helped explain nuclear fission.
It was discovered in 1982 in Germany.
It lasts only milliseconds—barely enough to study.
apps: Group 9 Chemistry Test
Chemists study its properties to see if it acts like its lighter family members, Iridium and Rhodium.
Its expected behavior is to be a noble (unreactive) metal, like Iridium, but experiments are extremely difficult.
Unlocking Super-Heavy Synthesis
Its discovery confirmed the use of the cold fusion method for creating new super-heavy elements.
It was created by fusing Bismuth-209 and Iron-58, proving this technique works for heavier elements.
Nuclear Decay Chain Research
Scientists use it to trace a long decay chain that leads to more stable, lighter elements.
It acts as a starting point, and its decay products are tracked to understand the stability of many different nuclei.
Theoretical Atomic Structure
Used as a key data point to test and refine models of the most complex electron shells.
Its existence helps theorists map the electron arrangement for the largest and most short-lived atoms.
sources: Bismuth-209 atoms hit with Iron-58 ions (cold fusion).
The process of fusing lighter atoms into Meitnerium.
The decay product of some heavier, man-made elements (e.g., Roentgenium).
Extremely rare atoms are created and detected one by one.
ccs: Meitnerium is so rare and short-lived that scientists have not yet been able to confirm any chemical compounds.

ffs: Named after Darmstadt, Germany, where it was discovered.
Created by smashing nickel and lead atoms together.
apps: Group 10 Chemistry Model
Scientists predict its chemistry should be similar to Platinum, Palladium, and Nickel.
Its expected property is to be a very noble (unreactive) metal, which forms bonds weakly, like its lighter cousins.
Long-Term Decay Study
Research focuses on finding a longer-lived isotope that would allow for chemical studies.
Scientists are searching for a Darmstadtium isotope that might be located on the 'Island of Stability' for better study.
Cold Fusion Synthesis
Its discovery further proved the success of using 'cold fusion' reactions for heavy elements.
It was made by fusing a very light atom (Nickel) with a very heavy target atom (Lead) to create the new element.
Testing Nuclear Theory
Used as a test case for advanced theories on nuclear binding energy and stability.
Its short lifespan helps nuclear physicists confirm their complex calculations on the limits of atomic size.
sources: Lead-208 atoms hit with Nickel-62 ions (cold fusion).
Bismuth-209 atoms hit with Cobalt-59 ions.
The process of fusing lighter atoms into Darmstadtium.
The decay product of some heavier, man-made elements (e.g., Livermorium).
ccs: Darmstadtium has an extremely short lifespan, so scientists have not yet been able to make or study any of its compounds.

ffs: Named after Wilhelm Roentgen, discoverer of X-rays.
It's so short-lived it's measured in microseconds.
apps: Group 11 Noble Metal Test
Studied to see if it acts like its lighter family members: Gold, Silver, and Copper.
The goal is to see if it behaves like a noble metal (unreactive) or if its chemistry is changed by its extreme weight.
Testing Chemical Stability
Used as a key data point for computer models predicting super-heavy element stability.
Its extremely short lifespan helps confirm the predicted instability of elements in this mass range.
Cold Fusion Reaction
Created by fusing Bismuth with Nickel atoms in an accelerator.
The method used to create Roentgenium is called cold fusion and is key for synthesizing many super-heavy elements.
Probing Relativistic Effects
Its expected unique chemical behavior is a critical test for relativistic quantum chemistry.
The massive nucleus and fast electrons are thought to change its color and how it bonds, unlike Gold.
sources: Bismuth-209 atoms hit with Nickel-64 ions (cold fusion).
The process of fusing lighter atoms into Roentgenium.
The decay product of some heavier, man-made elements (e.g., Copernicium).
Extremely rare atoms are created and detected one by one.
ccs: Roentgenium vanishes so fast that scientists have not yet been able to make or study any of its compounds.

ffs: It's one of the heaviest elements ever made.
It was almost named “Copernicum” but got changed last minute.
apps: Group 12 Volatility Test
Its ability to turn into gas is compared to Mercury, Cadmium, and Zinc.
Studies show that Copernicium is even more volatile (easily turned into gas) than Mercury, despite being much heavier.
Noble Gas Behavior
Its expected behavior is more like a noble gas than a transition metal.
Due to extreme electron speed, its outer shell is tightly closed, making it very unreactive like a noble gas.
Direct Observation Research
One of the few super-heavy elements whose atoms have been separated and observed chemically.
Scientists used a special detector to confirm its atoms interact very weakly with surfaces.
Island of Stability Clues
Some of its isotopes are slightly more stable, hinting at the theoretical Island of Stability.
Finding longer-lived isotopes helps nuclear physicists predict where the most stable heavy elements are located.
sources: Lead-208 atoms hit with Zinc-70 ions (cold fusion).
The process of fusing lighter atoms into Copernicium.
The decay product of some heavier, man-made elements (e.g., Flerovium).
Atoms are studied by their interaction with gold surfaces in the gas phase.
ccs: Scientists predict this compound might be stable enough to exist, similar to the compound made by Mercury, the element above it.

ffs: Named after Japan, its country of discovery.
It was the first element named by Asian scientists.
apps: Group 13 Metal Check
Studied to see if it follows the chemical patterns of Boron, Aluminum, and Thallium.
Its primary oxidation state is predicted to be +1, which is unusual for this group, due to relativistic effects.
Relativistic Chemistry Test
Its chemical reactions are a crucial test of how electron speed changes bonding.
Theory predicts its 7s electrons are so fast they act heavier, which changes how the 7p electrons bond.
Hot Fusion Creation
It was created by bombarding Bismuth with a Zinc beam.
Its discovery used a different method than elements 107-112, using a hotter reaction to fuse atoms.
Decay Chain Marker
Used as a marker in a long decay chain that can be traced all the way back to the parent element, Tennessine ($	ext{Ts}$).
Its existence and decay pattern confirms the creation of elements like Tennessine and Moscovium.
sources: Bismuth-209 atoms hit with Zinc-70 ions (cold fusion).
The process of fusing lighter atoms into Nihonium.
The decay product of some heavier, man-made elements (e.g., Moscovium).
Purified from complex mixtures of other heavy elements.
ccs: Scientists predict this compound would form if they could get enough Nihonium to react with Chlorine.
This compound is used in theoretical models to predict if Nihonium will act like its cousin, Thallium, but heavier.

ffs: Named after Russian physicist Georgy Flerov.
It might have strange metallic or noble gas properties—no one knows!
Confirmed as a superheavy element in 2012.
apps: Island of Stability Candidate
Its most stable isotopes are centered on a predicted point of enhanced nuclear stability.
Its long half-life (2 seconds) strongly suggests that a region of super-stable nuclei exists nearby.
Volatile Compound Studies
Experiments focus on its ability to form compounds that easily evaporate into a gas.
Current evidence suggests it is highly volatile and less reactive than lead, its lighter family member.
Group 14 Trend Test
Used to see if it acts like Lead, Tin, and Carbon in Group 14.
Its unusual volatility challenges the simple periodic trend that elements should become less volatile as they get heavier.
Nuclear Structure Mapping
Its existence and decay modes confirm the predicted location of the $	ext{Z}=114$ 'magic number'.
Scientists use its stability to prove that having 114 protons is a 'magic number' that makes the nucleus extra-stable.
sources: Plutonium-244 atoms hit with Calcium-48 ions (hot fusion).
The process of fusing lighter atoms into Flerovium.
The decay product of some heavier, man-made elements (e.g., Livermorium).
Atoms are studied by their interaction with gold surfaces in the gas phase.
ccs: This compound is a key prediction to see if Flerovium behaves like a metal in the same way its cousin, Lead, does.

ffs: One of the “newest” elements on the periodic table.
It was synthesized by scientists from Russia and the U.S.
apps: Decay Chain Source
Its discovery confirmed the existence of Nihonium ($	ext{Z}=113$) as one of its decay products.
Its creation and subsequent decay provided proof that elements 115 and 113 truly exist.
Group 15 Chemistry Test
Its expected behavior is similar to Bismuth, the heaviest element in Group 15 before it.
Scientists predict its most common state is +1 or +3—not +5 like the lighter Group 15 elements.
Hot Fusion Target
Created by smashing a heavy Calcium ion ($	ext{Z}=20$) into a target of Americium ($	ext{Z}=95$).
The method used, called hot fusion, is another successful technique for synthesizing super-heavy elements.
Search for Isomers
Researchers study its decay for 'isomers'—nuclei with the same number of protons and neutrons but different energy levels.
Finding these isomers helps map the complex energy levels and stability of heavy nuclei.
sources: Americium-243 atoms hit with Calcium-48 ions (hot fusion).
The process of fusing lighter atoms into Moscovium.
The decay product of some heavier, man-made elements (e.g., Tennessine).
Identified by tracking its decay into the confirmed element Nihonium.
ccs: This compound is predicted to be a stable salt, which helps scientists test the chemical pattern of its family group.

ffs: Named after Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California.
It was discovered in collaboration with Russian scientists.
It lasts less than a second before decaying.
apps: Group 16 Heavy Element Check
Predicted to have different chemical properties than its lighter family members, like Polonium and Tellurium.
Unlike the lighter elements in Group 16, Livermorium is expected to behave more like a metal.
Isotope Half-Life Studies
Its decay is tracked to confirm the half-lives of its super-heavy decay products.
Its isotopes decay into Flerovium ($	ext{Fl}$), which is important for understanding the stability of $	ext{Z}=114$.
Hot Fusion Synthesis
Created by fusing a heavy Calcium ion ($	ext{Z}=20$) into a Curium ($	ext{Z}=96$) target.
This particular combination of atoms helped confirm the predictability of heavy element creation using accelerator methods.
Search for Gas Phase
Scientists are researching if it is the first element in Group 16 that is not likely to form volatile hydrides (gas compounds).
This research helps test models of how bonding changes due to the relativistic effects in very heavy atoms.
sources: Curium-248 atoms hit with Calcium-48 ions (hot fusion).
The process of fusing lighter atoms into Livermorium.
The decay product of some heavier, man-made elements (e.g., Oganesson).
Identified by tracking its decay into the confirmed element Flerovium.
ccs: This compound is a key prediction for its simplest possible chemical reaction with oxygen.
Scientists predict this compound would form if Livermorium reacts with the highly reactive element Fluorine.

ffs: Named after the state of Tennessee.
Only a few atoms have ever been made.
It's part of the halogen group—though its behavior is unknown.
apps: Halogen Group Test
Scientists study its decay products to infer if it acts like Iodine or Bromine.
It is the first Group 17 element predicted to lose its electron easily, behaving more like a metal than a halogen.
Superheavy Collaboration
Its discovery was a major international effort between the U.S. and Russia.
It required a highly specialized target of Berkelium-249 from the U.S. and the powerful accelerator in Dubna, Russia.
Bridge to Og
Its decay chain confirms the creation of Oganesson ($	ext{Z}=118$) as one of its decay products.
The decay of Tennessine-294 led scientists directly to the detection of Oganesson-294.
Electron Shell Model
Its existence helps confirm the theoretical filling order of the final electron shells.
It fills the 7p shell, proving the basic quantum mechanical models still hold true for the heaviest atoms.
sources: Berkelium-249 atoms hit with Calcium-48 ions (hot fusion).
The process of fusing lighter atoms into Tennessine.
The decay product of some heavier, man-made elements (e.g., Oganesson).
Identified by tracking its decay into the confirmed element Moscovium.
ccs: Scientists predict this compound would be unstable and break apart easily, unlike the hydrogen compounds of lighter halogens.
This compound is a key prediction to see if Tennessine acts more like a metal than a typical halogen.

ffs: Named after Russian physicist Yuri Oganessian.
It's the heaviest element currently on the periodic table.
It might not behave like a noble gas at all—despite being one!
apps: Noble Gas Relativistic Test
It is the only element in the noble gas group (Group 18) that is predicted to be reactive.
Its massive size is expected to allow it to form chemical bonds, possibly behaving like a solid or liquid, not a gas.
Synthesis Endpoint
Its creation completes the seventh row of the periodic table.
This was the goal of nuclear chemists for decades, proving that the patterns of the table continue for the heaviest possible atoms.
Nuclear Magic Number
It is predicted to have the most stable nucleus of its super-heavy neighbors due to its 7p shell being full.
A filled electron shell gives it a slight advantage in nuclear stability, though its half-life is still very short.
Pushing the Limits of Matter
Its existence helps define the highest possible limit of the elements that can exist.
Studying Oganesson helps confirm theories on how atomic size and radioactivity are related.
sources: Californium-249 atoms hit with Calcium-48 ions (hot fusion).
The process of fusing lighter atoms into Oganesson.
The decay product of some heavier, man-made elements (e.g., Ununseptium).
Identified by tracking its decay into the confirmed element Livermorium.
ccs: This compound is highly predicted to be stable, which is a very surprising trait for a noble gas!
